Finishing my beer and waiting on Courtney to bring menus and maybe take our orders. No acknowledgement whatsoever for at least 20 minutes. Yes Courtney had just arrived at work.  Courtney evidently had to get settled. She did have to change the TV for herself or someone. She did need to carry on a non service related conversation with someone sitting at the bar.(for a while). She did have to text or get on Facebook or whatever was more important than we were although we were in plain view the entire time. I finally decided to go get my own menus and then noticed Brittaney telling Courtney something at which time she made her appearance at the table.  Took our drink orders. 2 local drafts. Went back to the phone. Finally after 5 minutes or so, another waitress asked if we needed anything and we said we had ordered beers. She volunteered to bring them (Kudos to her) and then Courtney decided to bring them.  Finally took our order. Brought our food and asked if we needed anything else. I decide since the Bushmills were $5 that sure I'd have another. She brought that and informed me it was $6 not $5???? Ok, only a buck but why was I told $5?? Then Brittaney decides she told me they were $2 off not $5 for whiskey. Ahem!! Not true! Not what she told me earlier! We all make mistakes but that got to me a little. Admit it if you screwed up alright.  Courtney apologizes for not getting to us earlier because she had just come in and had 20 different things to do. As I stated before, TV, chat chat chat chat, stand around and play on phone. And even if that were so was there NO ONE around to take orders in the meantime?? Yeah, there was! SMH! HORRIBLE SERVICE!!! On a positive note, the food was pretty good although greasy.

Overall:  - For the food alone, 98% of the menu is incredibly delicious and the kitchen staff seem very kind. A couple things aren't good, but the menu is great otherwise for 5 Stars there and for their kitchen staff. - For the service from bartenders and servers, 70% are great. But about 5 of 13 and their bus-boy are terrible.  - For management, as I've mentioned, they are insane and do not know how to please customers and think if they do ANYTHING for them, whether it's replacing a meal, giving a slight discount, or a free dessert, they strut like they've done the best work in their life (and they let you know it). And also, don't bother complaining about anyone, especially the 30% of the bad servers or the bus-boy who has an attitude with everything from the trash can to the lovely newlyweds that were just sat).  - The prices are high. Granted, portions are huge for a lot of things, but most items are good reheated. If you order anything that has gravy or a sauce on it, ask for it on the side so if you do take it home it won't be soggy and you can reheat it better. And reheat anything from there in the oven if possible. Pretty much 375* for 5-8 minutes does the trick for. The drinks are high too. Most drafts are $6-$7 for a pint....some are a 20 oz cup, some are 16 oz.....it's just not consistent and the most expensive draft is the Red Clay Cherry Cider that comes in maybe 12 ozs for $7!!!! That's crazy expensive.     To sum it up: Food is decent and authentic. However, the experience as a whole is pretty bad. Most of the servers are great, but there are a couple bad seeds that can ruin your dining experience from genuinely not caring about your experience. Management is INSANELY TERRIBLE. There are two managers, the owner and the chef, equally unapproachable and they will not compensate or replace anything for you. They make it seem like whatever is going on is your fault and guilt you for it. If they do happen to do something to replace a wrong/bad item, they act like they've given you the world. So, I hope you don't have to ask for a manager to help you. I really think with 2 new managers and replace the bus-boy and like 3-5 bad/rude servers, you may have a good thing going. It's also always hot there. ALWAYS hot. They always say the fans are "broken" and act like the air conditioner doesn't exist. Don't waste your time.

Big Ben is a neighborhood staple and a great casual spot with a European feel. The ambiance in an old mill building gives it a certain charm with the pub style. The fish and chips are delicious and they always have delicious British beers like Boddingtins and Newcastle on tap.

BLUF: I was full when I left, but felt like I paid too much.  I went to Big Ben one Sunday night primarily because it was within walking distance of Tremont Music Hall, where I was going to a concert later that night. I ordered a steak and kidney pie, a glass of Crispin (which happened to be on special that night, conveniently), and a slice of their sweet potato maple layered cheesecake.   The pie was all right, but I discovered I wasn't a big fan of kidney. Definitely should've gone for steak and mushroom instead. The sides that came with it were fine, but nothing special.   The cheesecake, on the other hand, was very good. However, I'm not sure it was quite worth $8 a slice.  In the end, the food was all very filling, but nothing special and not worth what I paid.

Big Ben is by far my favorite place to spend a weekend morning. As a huge Arsenal fan, this is the spot to watch my favorite team play. The breakfast is always fantastic, and for the later games the salads are great (steak salad is the best I've ever had). Highly recommended!

I went to this place the other evening because some other plans had fallen through, which I was disappointed with. I had been here before and liked it. This time, however, was exceptional.  The blond waitress that's been there forever is the absolute best. I enjoyed my food, the atmosphere and the service! Very happy!

Best, and most authentic British Pub in Charlotte.  I would probably give them 5 stars, if they got rid of the corny Union Jack neckties the waitstaff wear.  Their fish and chips are the best in Charlotte - always crispy outside, moist Haddock inside, huge portion as well.  For those that wish the old location had not burned down, forcing the move to SouthEnd: yes, the pub has lost some of it's "pub" charm, but let's admit it: it's now a better restaurant.  Excellent cottage pie, tin miners cornish pasty, bangers and mash, and if you're feeling healthy, the black and blue salad.  Nearest place to my house that serves Spaten on tap.  If you happen to be there on a soccer weekend, make sure you don your red and white and pull for The Arsenal!  The pub is the semi-official meeting spot for The Arsenal supporters club, the Queen City Gooners.

I've visited here twice, once awhile ago for an impromptu birthday dinner and again last night to watch the Women's World Cup Championship. For the first visit, they were accommodating for a last minute large party.   Last night, the environment was fun for soccer, but not to rowdy, as there were mostly 40 somethings present. I had a mimosa and a Pimm's something, both which were good. The drink wasn't watered down and our waitress, Eady, was very kind and always within eyeshot. Kudos to her on such a busy night.   The table shared the crab and artichoke dip. The pita chips with it were warm and soft enough. I highly recommend the crab dip. There was also the Ploughman's platter. I didn't taste any of it, but my friends seemed to enjoy. High marks for good service!

If you've ever traveled to England, or wanted to, Big Ben will give you a taste of across the pond without the plane ticket. It definitely resembles a traditional pub in England, slightly dark, very old, and a true love for all things Union Jack.   As for food, I can only attest for some appetizers, but both the Scotch eggs and bubble and squeak were spot on and delicious. If you've never had a scotch egg, I highly recommend trying it. It's a hard boiled egg rolled in breakfast sausage and fried (or sometimes baked). The bubble and squeak was of generous portion and equal parts sprouts and mashed.   Overall, I enjoyed popping in here and would certainly come back to try a traditional dinner.

A friend suggested Big Ben when we were in Charlotte for a day. The service was excellent and they had decent beer specials. Nice decor as well! I ordered the turkey wrap with a cup of their soup of the day, which was bacon, spinach and cheese. The soup was amazing! The turkey wrap was pretty standard, nothing special, but it was good. If I lived in the area, I could see myself hanging out here a lot!

Their fish & chips were a DREAM!  The fish was very fresh and cooked to perfection.  It is very filling and you honestly do not need to order any appetizer or dessert because it's more than enough.  Definitely a great spot for date night or a small family to get together.  Great recommendation!
I only came for drinks but I enjoyed it a lot! A very homie feeling when you walk in and a friendly staff. The menu is a little weird and on the pricey side but overall I liked it a lot!
So seeing they had breakfast... I just had to come back the next day...  This is breakfast http://instagram.com/p/dKCyKeNkw3/  Well it is not the most healthiest but darn is it sooooo good.
Very authentic pub for a pint! The atmosphere is great especially for watching soccer games! The staff is extremely friendly and always attentive. A must visit for soccer games!
Weirdly, they have my favorite burger in Charlotte. Haven't tried any English food, but if you want a burger from somewhere new, try them out.

If I could give a half mark it would be 2.5 - I give three because my server was really really nice and super helpful. As a Brit I was looking forward to some decent home cooked traditional food - I chose the steak and kidney pie. I was told it was homemade. I know what a pie out of a can both looks and tastes like and that's what I got. Not impressed at all and as a British pub, poor poor representation.

This bar has potential, but it is in the wrong type of building and doesn't have the right things going on.  With this place I expect a dingy hole in the wall for a place like this.  It was a little too clean, and the ceiling was too high.  I apologize for rating it based on the looks because I enjoyed the beer and the bartender, but it just didn't feel right for the kind of bar it was suppose to be in my eyes.  Also, when I went there was trivia going on and it kind of depressed me.

I was in Charlotte to visit the NASCAR Museum and catch a concert. Stopped at Big Ben for dinner between the two. We were greeted as soon as we came in, and our waitress was friendly and helpful. Both my daughter and I ordered the fish and chips. The portion was huge and it was very good. I would definitely stop in again if in the area.

Great atmosphere-- when we were eating there was a live soccer game on and people were getting into it.  Menu was a little limited, but it had something for those that were willing to try british cuisine.  We tried the fish & chips, roast lamb, and steak and mushroom pie.  The food was alright, nothing amazing, but incredibly filling.

My Mom came in town, after being in Germany, and wanted a specific beer, which after my searching Big Bend was the only place in Charlotte that had it on top. Needless to say the beer was good, but the food was awesome! We ordered the fish & chips and a cheeseburger with fries and shared...Both were SO good. The best fish and chips I have had in Charlotte & the burger was cooked to perfection. The only reason for the 4 stars, the service was a little slow. I will definitely return!

3 words: SCOTTISH MEAT PIES!  I am so happy that it is still as good as I remember it from last summer.  Half price appetizer Wednesday made it twice as perfect. The pies were savory, and the crust was flaky even with the gravy. The meat with peas and carrots were excellent comfort food.  I wasn't as happy about the wings, they were a little over fried, but I will give it another try just to taste the curry buffalo sauce. But all is forgiven the moment I took another bite if the meat pie.   FYI, $4 pint night Tuesdays, and $10.95 all traditional British dinners (exclude the steak) on Thursdays.   I will be British (again, yes, I used to be British by national even if I don't look it) more often since it's around the corner from my work :)

Visited here for the first time on April 17 with a friend.  I was a bit concerned at first because there wasn't many people inside. The server we had was the only one working the front and bar. I have to say that Nichole was phenomenal. She made some recommendations that we loved. The food was great and Nichole was absolutely incredible. This is one place I will be visiting again and as often as possible.

I visited for a weekday lunch, when the restaurant was pretty dead - I'm sure it's more lively in the evening, and that dishes geared toward a dinner crowd are considerably better. I had the British BLT which was ok - bread was overly toasted (nearly burnt) and it was quite dry - really needed more mayo or something. Nice beer selection - was happy to see that they had Old Speckled Hen!

A great selection of British beers and British food, Big Ben is the best in Charlotte for as close to proper English food as an American palate can determine. My wife is an UK import and she gives Big Ben the thumbs up.  Ordering from the dinner menu, we started off with a Scotch Egg (a boiled egg encased in a sausage wrapper then briefly fried) which was served with English relish. After that was cleared, our dinner arrived. I had a cottage pie, which was excellent. Plenty of meat and vegetables and actual (not from packet) mashed potatoes. My wife enjoyed the lamb dinner, which was a medium size pile of sliced lamb with steamed veggies and potatoes, covered in a zingy brown gravy. (On previous visits, I found the chicken curry to be very flavorful and not too spicy.)  Desserts were the only place where Big Ben lets it down. The Sherry Trifle was labeled as "traditional" but it seemed to be mostly canned whipped cream with very few lady's fingers. It was way too sweet and we ended up sending it back.  For two, with one appetizer, two entrees, three beers (one domestic, two imports) and a dessert, our tab was $70. While the food and service was great, this seems a little on the high side.  On some nights, they have music in the downstairs lounge. Even with the door closed, the smoke comes up from there as well as too much of the loud music. If that bothers you, try sitting on the other side of the restaurant. There's also a full bar if you just want drinks and (warning: English ahead) crisps.  They have a small parking behind the place and you're not supposed to park on the street. Overflow parking is across the street and down the hill, next to the Bank of America. It's clearly labeled but I think it could use a bit more lighting at night.  All told, a four star place. When we want to eat English, we're here!
Edie and Barb are great for service and add alot to this place. The food is phenomenal and would recommend to anyone that is near Southend...  Killer fish and chips...
Great food, friendly staff, excellent service. I've been here many times and always enjoy myself. Pints are always on special and the atmosphere/decor is relaxing.
The food is amazing. Fish and chips and the roast beef (with mash potatoes) were insanely good. You MUST try the Yorkshire pudding!!!
Nice spot, huge portions, friendly service, don't attempt to eat remotely healthy here!

Small place with friendly service.    If you're up for bangers & mash, you will enjoy the breakfast here. I had a great breakfast special on a circular croissant. They said it was a special, but I would ask for it if I returned.

Very good, got there at 6pm on a Saturday night and got right in. I had a steak and mushroom pie it was very good. At $14 dollars it wasn't  a bad price. It is expensive if you compare it to the dollar menu at McDonalds, but the meal was worth the price. I have to go back and try the fish n chips they look very good.

This new location is quite a surprise. It as a lot of fun and the food was good. Watching soccer on the big screen with some diehard fans actually added to the experience rather than make you not want to go back again. My wife had the fish and chips and loved it. It has a great atmosphere, great people and even live music on the weekends. This is a place you need to go to at least once and then be surprised by how many times you want to go back.

I love this place!  I tend to forget about it until my urge for Fish n' Chips kicks into high gear.  The bar is beautiful and reminds me of being in London during college.  I always have excellent service and food!

This is not the first time we have been to Big Ben Pub ...There are a lot of great things about this particular restaurant. Just to name a few, it is right next-door to savory Spice, it has a great patio, even though it backs up to the train (which is really quiet and kind a cool when it goes by), And the atmosphere is awesome...(this Total English pub is authentic, which is validated by the fact that I have actually been to London and Watford England having eaten and drank "Real Ale", served by a 1 armed/1 eyed bartender).  Big Ben pub is a wonderful dining experience and they have great beers on tap... Please take the time to try their chicken pot pie!

Maybe I just don't like British pub food but everything I ate was extremely underwhelming. I decided to go all out and get the Cornish Pasty but it sucked. The potatoes and gravy were bland, the vegetables were flavorless, and the pasty was gross. If I ever come back here it'll be strictly for a beer.

This is my favorite bar in south end.  They have great fish and chips, rotating monthly specials, live music on Fridays, and British brunch on Sunday's.  They have a projector they lower for big games and hands down this is the best place to watch soccer games in south end.  My most favorite thing about this place though, is its local.  If you live in south end and go here every 2-4 weeks like we do, you'll see the same friendly faces and they'll remember your name (and your drinks).  Very laid back bar with a great neighborhood feel to it - definitely worth five stars.
